description: Codex polecats sit at suggestion prompts and ignore both 'gt nudge' and 'gt session inject -m'. The nudge goes through (no error) but codex doesn't pick it up. Likely because codex's UI handles input differently from claude's. Need to investigate how to actually send input to a codex session via tmux, or if codex needs a different mechanism (maybe feeding to stdin directly).
title: gt nudge doesn't work on codex polecats — injected messages ignored

description:
Codex GPT-5.3 polecats consistently fail to work autonomously. Observed problems:

1. **Suggestion prompt stall**: Codex shows suggestion prompts ('› Explain this codebase', '› Implement {feature}', '› Use /skills') and sits there indefinitely instead of processing the assigned work. Requires manual intervention (type prompt + Enter, sometimes double Enter).

2. **prompt_mode fix was partial**: Changed codex agents from prompt_mode 'none' to 'arg' in town config — this got the startup prompt passed to codex CLI, but codex still doesn't reliably act on it.

3. **gt nudge ineffective**: Sending nudges via gt nudge doesn't reliably unstick codex. The text appears in the tmux pane but codex doesn't process it.

4. **Hung background tasks**: Codex spawns background terminals (e.g. 'make test') that hang for 25+ minutes with no timeout or cleanup.

5. **Model stubbornness**: Even after receiving clear instructions, codex often loops back to suggestion prompts or does printf statements instead of actual work.

6. **Session naming**: Codex tmux sessions use 'cm-<name>' format, different from expected 'cmtestsuite/polecats/<name>'.

Investigation needed:
- Is the codex CLI handling the startup prompt correctly?
- Does codex need a different prompt format/structure than claude?
- Should we wrap codex with a startup script that forces it past suggestion prompts?
- Are there codex CLI flags we're missing that enable autonomous mode?
- Should the witness have codex-specific health checks?
- Compare codex behavior with --dangerously-bypass-approvals-and-sandbox vs without
title: Codex GPT-5.3 polecats: stubborn, won't auto-process work

description: Mayor should check gt mail inbox: after dispatch batches, after status checks, when system reminders mention mail, before idle. Currently only checks on startup. Polecats sending urgent blockers need timely responses. Add to prime template work philosophy section.
title: Mayor periodic mail polling between tasks

description: Witness should detect stuck polecats: (1) same error 3+ times without new approach, (2) nudge responses are status reports without action, (3) no git changes for >15 min while active, (4) context <20% without task completion. Actions: nudge with specific fix, escalate to mayor after 2 failed nudges, optionally nuke and resling to different model.
title: Polecat stuck detection: witness should detect idle/looping polecats

title: gt session nudge doesn't exist — command is gt nudge

description:
The mayor repeatedly fails to capture codex polecat tmux panes because it guesses wrong session names. Pattern of mistakes:

1. Tried 'cmtestsuite/polecats/chrome' — wrong, actual name is 'cm-chrome'
2. Codex polecat tmux sessions use 'cm-<name>' format (e.g. cm-chrome, cm-dust, cm-nitro)
3. Claude polecat tmux sessions may use a different naming pattern
4. Mayor should learn the naming convention or use 'tmux list-sessions' first before attempting capture-pane

Also: codex suggestion prompts (the '›' lines like 'Explain this codebase', 'Implement {feature}') require typing a real prompt and pressing Enter — sending blank Enter just accepts the suggestion. The mayor needs to understand:
- How to identify when codex is at a suggestion prompt vs actually working
- How to properly nudge codex (type prompt text then Enter, sometimes needs double Enter)
- That codex prompt_mode must be 'arg' not 'none' (fixed in config but worth documenting)

Improve gt polecat status / gt nudge / tmux interaction docs or mayor awareness so these mistakes stop recurring.
title: Mayor: learn codex tmux session naming and capture-pane patterns

description:
The witness should be aware of and flag codex-specific failure patterns during code review:

1. **Spin-loop detection**: Codex polecats often repeat the same failing approach 10+ times without trying alternatives. The witness should flag code that shows evidence of brute-force retry patterns rather than root-cause diagnosis.

2. **Ignored feedback**: When a polecat receives mail/nudges with specific technical guidance (e.g. 'IAC WILL ECHO is the issue, handle telnet negotiation') but continues the same approach, the witness should note this in review comments.

3. **Incomplete error handling**: Codex tends to write minimal error handling. The witness should flag missing error paths, especially around network I/O, telnet negotiation, and MUD protocol edge cases.

4. **Copy-paste without adaptation**: Codex often copies code patterns without adapting them to the specific context. The witness should check that imported/adapted code actually matches the local codebase conventions and types.

5. **Silent failures**: Codex polecats frequently produce code that compiles but silently fails at runtime. The witness should specifically look for:
   - Timeout values that are too short for MUD interactions
   - Missing telnet IAC/WILL/WONT handling
   - Regex patterns that don't account for ANSI escape codes
   - Hardcoded prompts that don't match the server profile

6. **Escalation awareness**: When reviewing codex polecat branches, the witness should check commit history for signs of thrashing (many small commits with similar messages) and recommend reassignment to a claude polecat if the pattern is detected.

Add these checks to the witness review checklist. This applies to ALL rigs, not just cmtestsuite.
title: Witness: detect and handle codex polecat stubbornness patterns

description:
Codex polecats sometimes complete their assigned work but never call 'gt done' or submit to the merge queue. The work sits on the polecat branch unreported. Symptoms:

- Polecat shows 'working' state but has actually finished
- Code is committed on the polecat branch but never pushed or submitted
- No gt done / gt mail sent to refinery
- Mayor has to manually check, salvage commits, and push

This may be related to gt-41u (codex stubbornness) — codex may not understand the Gas Town workflow (gt prime → work → gt done) even when AGENTS.md documents it. Or codex may hit a suggestion prompt after finishing and never execute the submission step.

Possible fixes:
- Wrap codex session with a post-work hook that auto-submits if commits exist
- Add explicit 'WHEN DONE: run gt done' to the molecule/formula prompt
- Witness should detect completed-but-unsubmitted work (commits on branch, idle session)
- Consider a codex-specific formula that's more prescriptive about the submission step
title: Codex polecats fail to submit work to merge queue

description: When attempting 'gt peek' with no args to list all polecats, the command errors: 'accepts between 1 and 2 arg(s), received 0'. The natural desire-path for operators checking rig health is 'gt peek cmtestsuite' (rig-level) or just 'gt peek' to see all active polecats. Neither works without specifying a specific polecat name. Consider: (1) 'gt peek <rig>' should list all polecats in that rig with recent status, or (2) bare 'gt peek' shows a dashboard of all rigs/polecats. Currently you must know the exact polecat name (e.g. 'gt peek cmtestsuite/thunder') to get output.
title: gt peek: document or support bare invocation (no args)

description:
The mayor frequently gets errors using gt polecat commands (e.g. using 'gt polecat show' instead of 'gt polecat status', forgetting rig name argument for 'gt polecat list', etc).

Create a quick-reference doc or memory entry covering:

1. **gt polecat subcommands**: list, status, nuke, check-recovery, gc, git-state, identity, prune, remove, stale, session
2. **Common patterns**:
   - 'gt polecat list <rig>' requires rig name (or --all)
   - 'gt polecat status <rig>/<name>' for detailed status
   - 'gt polecat git-state <rig>/<name>' before nuking to check dirty files
   - 'gt polecat nuke <rig>/<name>' with --force for stuck ones
   - 'gt sling <bead> <rig> --agent <agent>' for dispatching with specific model
   - Batch sling: 'gt sling <b1> <b2> <b3> <rig> --agent <agent>'
3. **gt sling vs gt dispatch**: There is no 'dispatch' command. Use 'gt sling' for everything.
4. **Common mistakes to avoid**:
   - 'gt polecat show' → use 'status' instead
   - 'gt polecat list' without rig → add rig name or --all
   - 'gt dispatch' → use 'gt sling'
   - Slinging to yourself when you mean to spawn a polecat → specify rig as target

Update the mayor's memory file and/or create a doc that gets auto-loaded.
title: Mayor CLI awareness: document gt polecat subcommands and common patterns

description: Witness nudges should be diagnostic, not generic. When polecat is stuck: (1) read polecat's last output, (2) identify specific blocker, (3) suggest concrete next step, (4) if can't diagnose, escalate to mayor with context. Requires witness to analyze polecat output, not just check liveness.
title: Smarter witness nudges with actionable instructions

description: Two mail system bugs observed: (1) CODEX POLECATS CAN'T MAIL: Codex polecat (enclave) was stuck for 30+ minutes on a blocker but never mailed the mayor. When finally told to mail, the gt mail send command worked but the polecat had to be explicitly instructed to do it. Codex polecats don't have hooks so they never get the 'mail mayor when stuck' instruction injected. Need: add mail-on-blocker behavior to AGENTS.md (which codex reads) and to the polecat prime template. (2) MAYOR NOT NOTIFIED: When enclave did mail, the mayor wasn't notified until the next user prompt triggered the UserPromptSubmit hook. The system reminder said 'Continue your current task. When it completes, check these messages.' This means urgent blocker mail sits unread while the mayor works on other things. Need: incoming mail with keywords like 'blocker', 'stuck', 'urgent', 'help' should interrupt the mayor immediately, not queue for later. (3) NO PERIODIC POLLING: Mayor has no periodic mail check. Should poll inbox after every dispatch/status-check cycle.
title: Mail delivery failure: codex polecats can't send mail and mayor not notified on receive

description:
Claude polecats frequently finish their assigned bead work but then sit at an empty Claude Code prompt (the '❯' ready prompt) waiting for new input instead of calling 'gt done' to submit. Observed pattern:

- Polecat completes work, commits code, shows summary
- Claude reaches idle prompt asking 'what would you like to work on next?'
- Polecat state still shows 'working' but no progress is being made
- Mayor has to manually nudge or the polecat just sits there burning context

This is different from codex suggestion prompts (gt-41u) — Claude polecats understand the workflow but seem to forget the final 'gt done' step, or they complete it but the session stays alive waiting for more input.

Possible fixes:
- Formula/molecule should include stronger 'AFTER COMPLETING: run gt done immediately, do not wait' instructions
- Witness should detect idle Claude sessions (ready prompt with no activity for N minutes)
- Session timeout: auto-terminate sessions that have been idle at prompt for >5 minutes
- Hook on session idle: auto-run gt done if work branch has commits ahead of main
- Check if 'Landing the Plane' section in CLAUDE.md is being followed
title: Claude polecats idle at empty prompts after completing work

description: Mayor keeps running 'gt session check cmtestsuite/ghoul' — the check subcommand takes a rig name, not a rig/polecat path. Correct usage: 'gt session check cmtestsuite'. Update docs or add better error message.
title: gt session check takes rig name, not rig/polecat

description:
Polecats spawned from branches that predate CLAUDE.md/AGENTS.md symlink changes end up with missing or stub instruction files. Claude polecats without CLAUDE.md get no beads integration, no landing-the-plane protocol, no CIRCLEMUD.md reference — they're basically flying blind.

Root cause: gt sling creates worktrees from polecat branches that may be behind main. If CLAUDE.md was added or modified on main after the branch point, the polecat never gets it.

Fix options:
1. **gt sling post-spawn hook**: After creating worktree, verify CLAUDE.md exists and has expected content (beads integration section). If missing/stale, pull from main.
2. **Worktree creation always rebases on main**: gt sling already does this but beads backup conflicts can cause the rebase to fail silently, leaving the worktree on an old commit.
3. **Session start pre-check**: Before starting the agent session, verify critical files exist (CLAUDE.md, AGENTS.md, CIRCLEMUD.md). Fail fast with clear error if missing.
4. **.beads/backup/ should be in .gitignore**: These files cause constant rebase conflicts and have zero value in polecat worktrees. Ignoring them would eliminate 90% of rebase failures.

The .beads/backup conflict issue is the deeper problem — every rebase hits it and polecats either skip the commit (losing real changes) or get stuck.
title: Polecat spawn: ensure CLAUDE.md present in worktree before session start

description: Systemic issue: Claude polecats complete their work, run gt done successfully (MR submitted to merge queue), but then sit at an idle prompt instead of exiting. This creates zombie sessions that consume polecat slots and require manual nuke cycles. Observed with 15+ polecats across multiple sling batches on 2026-02-27/28. The witness should detect idle-after-done polecats and clean them up, or gt done itself should exit the Claude Code session after successful submission. Current behavior forces the mayor to repeatedly check all polecats, verify they're done, and manually nuke them — burning mayor context on janitor work.
notes: Secondary issue: some polecats burn through 100% context before completing work (fury hit 0% on cm-v13, compacted, then couldn't recover). This may be related to the polecat prompt being too large, or the work beads being underspecified. Fury was assigned OasisOLC permission testing (cm-v13) and spent all context exploring code before writing tests.
title: Polecats don't self-terminate after gt done — zombie at idle prompt

description: Polecats hitting blockers should auto-mail mayor within 10 minutes. Add to polecat prime template: if same error 3 times or no progress for 10 min, mail mayor with error details, what was tried, and proposed alternatives. Don't just restate — propose solutions.
title: Polecat blocker escalation: auto-mail mayor when stuck >10 min

description:
Per-rig worker monitor patrol loop.

The Witness is the Pit Boss for your rig. You watch polecats, nudge them toward
completion, verify clean git state before kills, and escalate stuck workers.

**You do NOT do implementation work.** Your job is oversight, not coding.

## Persistent Polecat Model (gt-4ac)

Polecats persist after work completion — sandbox is preserved for reuse:

```
Polecat lifecycle: spawning → working → mr_submitted → idle (sandbox preserved)
MR lifecycle:      created → queued → processed → merged (Refinery handles)
```

Once a polecat calls gt done and submits an MR, it transitions to idle state.
The MR lifecycle continues independently in the Refinery. The polecat is NOT
nuked — its sandbox is preserved for reuse by future slings.

**CRITICAL**: Do NOT nuke polecats with pending MRs. The refinery needs the
remote branch to exist to process the merge. Nuking deletes the remote branch
and orphans the MR. See gt-6a9d.

**Key principle**: Polecat lifecycle is separate from MR lifecycle. Polecats
go idle after work, they are NOT destroyed.

## Design Philosophy

This patrol follows Gas Town principles:
- **Discovery over tracking**: Observe reality each cycle, with minimal agent-bead state for duration tracking
- **Events over state**: POLECAT_DONE mail triggers merge flow registration
- **Persistent by default**: Clean polecats go idle, sandbox preserved for reuse (gt-4ac)
- **Cleanup wisps for merge tracking**: Created when MR is pending in refinery
- **Task tool for parallelism**: Subagents inspect polecats, not molecule arms
- **Swim lane discipline**: Only close wisps YOU created. Wisp lifecycle for non-witness wisps is the reaper Dog's job. Report orphaned foreign wisps — never close them.

## Patrol Shape (Linear)

```
inbox-check ─► process-cleanups ─► check-refinery ─► survey-workers
                                                            │
         ┌──────────────────────────────────────────────────┘
         ▼
  check-timer-gates ─► check-swarm ─► patrol-cleanup ─► context-check ─► loop-or-exit
```

No dynamic arms. No fanout gates. No persistent nudge counters.
State is discovered each cycle from reality (tmux, beads, mail).
title: mol-witness-patrol

title: Polecat stuck detection: witness should detect idle/looping polecats

Currently stuck polecats go unnoticed until the mayor manually checks.

description:
Codex reads AGENTS.md as system context but doesn't auto-execute instructions from it like Claude does with CLAUDE.md. Claude sees 'run gt prime' in CLAUDE.md and runs it. Codex sees the same in AGENTS.md but just sits at its suggestion prompt waiting for user input.

The fix: when gt spawns a codex polecat session, it should pass 'gt prime' as the initial [PROMPT] argument to the codex CLI, e.g.:
  codex -m gpt-5.3-codex --dangerously-bypass-approvals-and-sandbox 'gt prime'

Or inject the prompt via tmux immediately after session start.

This is why all codex polecats sit idle after spawn — they have the instructions but don't act on them. Combined with gt-3mk (nudges don't work on codex), this makes codex polecats effectively unable to self-start.
title: Codex polecats need initial prompt injection at session start
